awd_titl_txt: Regulation of Energy Organelle Dynamics in Plants
awd_abstract_narration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT
Peroxisomes and mitochondria are ubiquitous, multifunctional, and highly dynamic organelles that mediate a variety of metabolic functions in eukaryotes. In plants, these organelles together with chloroplasts are essential to energy production and metabolism. The abundance and morphology of mitochondria and peroxisomes are highly regulated to adapt to the need of a plant. Among components of the organelle division machineries, the Arabidopsis dynamin-related proteins DRP3A and DRP3B are key mediators for the fission of both mitochondria and peroxisomes. This project further investigates the molecular mechanisms that control organelle dynamics, focusing on the post-translational regulation of the function of DRP3 by protein phosphorylation and by a phospholipid, cardiolipin, whose function is largely unknown in plants. This research addresses a fundamental question in eukaryotic biology in a quantitative manner, using in vivo and in vitro approaches and combining genetic, cell biological and biochemical strategies. Knowledge will be integrated from single proteins and lipids to sub-cellular machineries and plant development. Given the essential roles of peroxisomes and mitochondria in plant development and energy metabolism, this study will have agricultural and economical relevance, as knowledge gained may provide molecular basis for developing strategies for rational engineering of plant metabolism, bioenergy production, and defense.

BROADER IMPACTS
Personnel on the project will participate in training undergraduate and high school students in summer research, outreaching to local schools, and providing educational opportunities to the scientific and broader communities through lectures. The PI will remain active in including women and individuals from underrepresented groups in the project.

por.por_cntn:
Peroxisomes, mitochondria, together with chloroplasts, are key organelles involved in energy metabolism. The overarching goal of this project is to understand the molecular mechanisms of the dynamic behavior of plant peroxisomes and mitochondria, using the model organism Arabidopsis thaliana. The first specific aim is to determine the regulation of key proteins involved in mitochondrial and peroxisome biogenesis and division. The second aim is to understand the role of the phospholipid cardiolipin in mitochondrial dynamics and function. Our accomplishments include the following:

I. We discovered the role of the mitochondrial phospholipid cardiolipin (CL) in mitochondrial morphogenesis and division, which is, at least partially, through stabilizing the mitochondrial division complex dynamin-related protein 3 (DRP3), and it role in programmed cell death in response to stress.

II. We identified the first plant mitochondrial membrane-bound deubiquitinase (UBP27), which contributes to mitochondrial morphogenesis by possibly facilitating the recycling of the organelle division proteins DRP3A and DRP3B.

III. We identified the Arabidopsis RING-type E3 ubiquitin ligase SP1 (suppressor of ppi1 locus1) and its homolog SPL1 as triple localized membrane proteins that target to peroxisomes, mitochondria and chloroplasts. SP1 promotes the degradation of the peroxisome protein docking complex components, whereas SPL1 antagonizes the function of SP1. Our work suggests that degradation of proteins in organelle protein import/dynamics by the ubiquitin-proteasome system may constitute an important regulatory mechanism in coordinating the development of metabolically linked organelles in higher eukaryotes.

IV. We identified Arabidopsis Forkhead-Associated Domain Protein 3 (FHA3) as a novel nuclear protein that represses peroxisome division by inhibiting the transcription of PEX11b, which encodes a peroxisome division factor.

V. We completed the analysis of peroxisomal proteome from senescent leaves, which revealed peroxisome-mediated stress response networks.

Our work has important implications in eukaryotic cell biology and may provide a paradigm for the study of organelle biogenesis in other higher eukaryotes. Our findings also provide a knowledge base to agricultural efforts to improve crops for more robust performance under stress conditions. Work from this project has led to the publication of 11 research articles. The PI has given 25 talks on work in this project, and materials have been disseminated upon request. Over the course of the project, 3 postdoc associates, 2 graduate students, 7 undergraduates and 1 high school student were trained. Most trainees have since moved on to more advanced levels of research training, and one has established his own lab as a university professor.
